questions.text: A police sub-inspector brings the accused in a rape case to a doctor and requests a medical examination. He believes that examination findings would yield evidence to prove the offense allegedly committed. However, the accused is not cooperative. What is the next course of action by the doctor?

choices.text: Request police officer for a court order
Refuse to carry out medical examination without consent
Wait until the accused gives consent

questions.solution:
The next course of action by the doctor is to perform the medical examination by force. 

Section 53 CrPC deals with the examination of the accused by a doctor using force, in the event that the examination has been requested by a police officer (designation of Sub-Inspector and above). The intention behind such a request must be to procure evidence regarding the offense allegedly committed by the accused [Sec. 53 (1) CrPC]. If the person is accused of rape, a medical examination may be carried out by force (in the event of non-cooperation) by the provisions made by Sec. 53A CrPC.

Whenever the person of a female is examined, the medical examination must be carried out only by, or under the direct supervision of a female doctor [Sec. 53 (2) CrPC].

Such an examination is applicable to the testing of blood, blood stains, semen, swabs, sputum, hair samples, and fingernail clippings. 

Other options:

Consent is mandatory for the examination of a victim in criminal cases. Performing an examination by force or by availing of a court order is not allowed for the examination of a victim.

questions.text: A patient was brought into the emergency room by his friend with features of acute intoxication that are attributed to nicotine alkaloids derived from the plant shown below. What category of poisons does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Nicotine is a plant alkaloid derived from the Nicotiana tabacum plant shown in the image above. It is a cardiac poison.

All components of this plant are poisonous except its ripe seeds. Leaves of this plant contain toxic alkaloids, like nicotine, anabasine, nornicotine and lobeline. It is a cardiac poison that initially stimulates autonomic ganglia to produce symptoms of acute intoxication (tachycardia, bradycardia,  hypotension, tachypnea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and headache). These symptoms later subside to give way to respiratory depression and collapse.

Other cardiac poisons are:

Digoxin is a cardiac poison derived from the roots, leaves, and seeds of the plant Digitalis purpurea (shown below). It acts to prolong the diastolic period of the cardiac muscle. Bradycardia, extrasystoles, ventricular tachycardia, and fibrillation are manifestations of toxicity. Ocular symptoms such as photopsia (colour changes), scotoma, and transient amblyopia can also be seen.

Aconite is a cardiac poison derived mainly from the root and root tubers of the plant Aconite napellus (shown below). Symptoms of intoxication are due to action on the voltage-gated sodium channels on the cell membrane of nerves, and skeletal and smooth muscles. Symptoms consist of intestinal (nausea, vomiting, perioral tingling and numbness, abdominal pain and diarrhoea), cardiovascular (chest pain, palpitations, hypotension, bradycardia), neurological (vertigo and restlessness), ocular (hippus - pupils alternately contract and dilate, diplopia and impaired vision.)

Aconite is an ideal homicidal poison - 

  • Cheap and easily available 
  • Lethal dose is small and short fatal period
  • Taste can be masked by giving it with betel leaves 
  • Cannot be detected by chemical analysis.
  • Also used as an abortifacient, cattle and arrow poison.

Thevetin is a cardiac poison derived from the plant Cerebra Thevetia (yellow oleander). All parts of the plant are poisonous. Symptoms of intoxication are characterized by vomiting, diarrhoea, headache, dizziness, mydriasis, and loss of muscular power. Cardiovascular signs include a weak and irregular pulse rate with hypotension. Possible complications are heart block and cardiorespiratory failure. 

Quinine - Derived from the bark of the Cinchona plant and it causes cinchonism due to repeated therapeutic exposures its symptoms are tinnitus, vertigo, deafness, scotoma, hypoglycemia and arrhythmias. 

Other options:

Option A: Spinal poisons- Strychnine (Strychnus nux vomica), gelsemium. Strychnine acts at the ventral horn by blocking the postganglionic glycine receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem. The blockade of these receptors by strychnine results in unopposed muscle contraction, resulting in the classical clinical features such as tonic-clonic seizures, opisthotonus (body arched in hyperextension) and risus sardonicus.

Option B: Deliriants -  Datura, belladonna, hyoscyamus, cannabis, cocaine.

Option C: Asphyxiants -  A toxic or non-toxic gas that causes respiratory embarrassment and leads to unconsciousness or death by asphyxiation. 

Asphyxiants can be classified into:

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about thallium poisoning?

choices.text: It gives no odour after death
It is an ideal homicidal agent
It can be detected in the ashes of the burnt body

questions.solution:
In thallium poisoning, postmortem examination reveals a garlicky odour from the mouth and nose. 

Thallium is odourless, tasteless, and water-soluble. The poisoning with this metal closely resembles a natural disease. Therefore, this is an ideal homicidal poison.

Thallium salts are used in dye and glass industries and as rodenticides and insecticides. In mild cases, joint pain, loss of appetite and drowsiness can occur. In severe cases, there is colicky pain, hair loss, vomiting, severe muscle and joint pains, motor and sensory neuropathies, convulsions, psychosis, optic neuritis, tremors delirium and coma. Madarosis (loss of outer third of eyebrows) is significant. Death occurs due to respiratory paralysis. On postmortem examination, it has a garlic-like odour, Mees lines may be present on nail. It can also be detected in the ashes of the burnt body i.e. after cremation.

Chronic thallium poisoning has a triad of alopecia, skin rashes, painful peripheral neuropathy and mental confusion with lethargy.

Treatment is mainly by stomach wash with potassium iodide or Prussian blue, activated charcoal. Hemodialysis is useful and forced diuresis can be given.

questions.text: All of the following are true about expert witness except:

choices.text: Witness Bata may be paid to Doctors even in Criminal Cases
Has the knowledge to draw conclusions from the facts available

questions.solution:
The first-hand knowledge Rule is applicable to common witness, not an expert witness.

A common witness is a person who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by him based on the first-hand knowledge rule (only facts perceived by him).

Section 45 of the Indian Evidence Act defines an expert witness. An expert witness is one who has acquired special knowledge, skill or experience in any science, art, subject, or profession. He could have acquired such knowledge by practice, observation, or careful studies.

If the witness is a doctor in private practice, he may request the court for conveyance charges and daily allowance according to the Government rules(even in criminal cases). As per law (Section 312 CrPC), he or she will be paid the travel allowances (TA) by the court. This is referred to as "Witness Bata".

The chemical examiner is also an expert witness

Also note:

A hostile witness is a person who is supposed to have some interest or motive for concealing a part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence.

questions.text: While studying the x-ray of a child brought to the casualty, the doctor notices a "string of beads" appearance in the paravertebral region. Which of the following conditions is this finding most likely associated with?
questions.solution:
String of beads appearance in the paravertebral region on an x-ray is associated with infantile whiplash syndrome. 

In battered baby syndrome/ Caffey syndrome / infantile whiplash syndrome, violent squeezing of the chest from side to side causes fracture of costochondral junctions and also along with the posterior angles of the rib. After callus formation which takes around 2 weeks, it gives a “string of beads” appearance in the paravertebral region on X-ray.

A battered child is one who is a victim of repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, inflicted by the parent or a guardian. The physical injury may also be associated with deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection.

It is usually seen in children less than 3 years of age with a history of emotional or financial problems in the family.

Laceration of the upper lip and tear of the fraenulum are frequently seen lesions, resulting from efforts to silence a crying child.

Bruises may be seen on either side of the chest, behind the axillae, and down the anterior chest wall, due to the child being gripped in a rough manner, between the perpetrator's hands and shaken. This shaking of a child leads to infantile whiplash syndrome, often resulting in subdural hematoma and intraocular bleeding in battered babies. Permanent brain damage can occur due to habitual, prolonged shaking. 

The most common cause of death is a head injury, followed by the rupture of any abdominal organ.

Other options:
Option A: Sandifer syndrome involves gastroesophageal reflux in infants resulting in episodes of generalized stiffening and opisthotonic posturing. This may be accompanied by apnea, staring, and minimal jerking of the extremities. These episodes often occur 30 min after a feed and in older children, it manifests with episodic dystonic or dyskinetic movements consisting of laterocollis, retrocollis, or torticollis.

Option C: Munchausen's syndrome involves feigning illness or injury and going from hospital to hospital for unnecessary investigations and treatment. It is seen in the adults themselves.

Option D: Sudden infant death syndrome is defined as the sudden and unexpected death of a seemingly healthy infant, and whose death remains unexplained even after a thorough case investigation, death scene examination, review of clinical history and a complete autopsy.

The above image is of a joule burn which is specific and diagnostic of electric burns and is found at the point of entry.  

Joule burn is a specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity and is found at the point of entry of the current. It is seen in accidents with high-tension currents. It is an endogenous thermal burn due to the heat generated in the body from electricity. These marks are round or oval, shallow craters, 1-2 cm in diameter, and raised borders around part or the whole of their circumference.
The crater floor is lined by pale flattened skin. The presence of an areola of blanched skin is seen at the periphery of the joule burn, which survives death and is pathognomonic of electrical damage.

Other important features of electrical injuries:

  • Flash / Spark burns - results when there is a high voltage electrical injury and contact between metal and skin is loose. It is an exogenous burn, keratin melts in the skin producing brownish keratin nodules with pale areola. Very high voltage currents produce massive destruction of tissue with loss of extremities and rupture of organs. 
  • Crocodile burns - multiple nodules on the skin due to high voltage electrical injury over a large body surface. 
  • Bone pearls or wax drippings - heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate which is seen in X-rays of limbs as typical round dense foci.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the primary health center with a history of snakebite. The area of the bite is painful and appears red and swollen. From his description, the snake that bit him had a triangular head with a V-shaped mark, as shown in the image below. All of the following statements regarding this snake bite are true, except ___.

choices.text: Death is due to shock and hemorrhage
Persistent bleeding from bite site is noticed
Bleeding and clotting time are prolonged

questions.solution:
From the patient's description and the image, the snake is most likely Russell's viper. The victims of Russell's viper may become oliguric within a few hours of the bite suggesting renal ischemia.

The Russell's viper has a flat and triangular head with a V-shaped mark, white in color, with the angle of the V pointing forwards. Along the back, it has three rows of diamond-shaped spots. Other points of identification include broad plates on its belly, the small scales on the head, and a shield beneath the tail divided into two rows. It is commonly found throughout India.

Russell's viper venom contains two proteases that affect the blood-clotting cascade. Though more than half the victims have minimal or no poisoning, few develop serious generalized poisoning. At the spot where venom is injected, the patient develops severe pain and the area around the bite becomes red and painful. Persistent bleeding from the bite site is a constant feature. Blisters begin to appear in some hours which progressively involves the entire limb. Skin temperature is raised. Intravascular hemolysis may lead to hemoglobinuria which progresses to renal failure.

Since the venom affects the blood-clotting cascade, the bleeding and clotting time are usually prolonged. Patients may develop hemorrhagic syndrome due to bleeding from various sites like gums, rectum, etc. Death is usually due to hemorrhagic shock.

questions.text: Hara-kiri is death by _____________
questions.solution:
Hara-kiri is death by stab in the abdomen.

Hara-kiri is an unusual type of suicide disembowelment connected with Japanese Samurai warriors. The victim with a short sword inflicts a single large abdominal stab wound into the left side, drawing the blade across to the right side and then turning it upwards producing an L-shaped cut. The sudden evisceration of the internal organs causes an immediate decrease in intraabdominal pressure and venous return resulting in collapse and death.

questions.text:
A woman was drugged with ketamine which was slipped into her drink without her knowledge by a stranger, intending to harm her. Her friends noticed that she was drugged and other eyewitnesses in the bar helped in apprehending the perpetrator. The accused is punishable under which section of the BNS/IPC?

BNS- Bharatiya Nayaya Sanhita; IPC- Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a person poisoning another person with a stupefying drug is punishable under BNS Sec 123 (328 IPC).

BNS Sec 123 (328 IPC) states that whoever administers to or causes to be taken by any person, any poison or any stupefying, intoxicating or unwholesome drug, or any other thing with intent to cause hurt to such person, or with intent to commit or to facilitate the commission of an offense, shall be punished with imprisonment up to ten years and also fine.

Other options:

BNS Sec 118(1) (324 IPC) - Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous means. This section states that whoever volun­tarily causes hurt by means of any poison or any corrosive substance shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

BNS Sec 118(2) (326 IPC) - Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous means. Offenders who voluntarily cause grievous hurt by means of any poison or any corrosive substance shall be pun­ished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

BNS Sec 286 (284 IPC)- deals with 'Negligent conduct with respect to poisonous substance' - It states that whoever does, with any poisonous substance, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any person, or knowingly, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

Date rape:

Sexual intercourse with a woman after sedating her.

  • Gamma-butyrolactone (GBL)
  • Rohypnol (flunitrazepam)

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical scenarios are correctly matched to the respective clauses application to these cases?
  1. A surgeon performs thyroidectomy after obtaining relevant informed consent from the patient, but the recurrent laryngeal nerve was injured intraoperatively. 
  2. A doctor performing life-saving procedures on a patient with life-threatening RTA injuries without obtaining consent.
  3. A surgeon concealing rare adverse outcomes of surgery to the anxious patient and revealing the details to close relatives of the patient.
  4. A surgeon accidentally left a cotton swab inside the abdomen post-laparotomy.

A- The doctrine of therapeutic privilege

B- Res Ipsa Loquitor

C- The doctrine of emergency

D- Medical maloccurrence
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B

Scenario 1:

Medical Maloccurrence:  The patient fails to respond properly or may suffer some adverse reactions to the drug which may lead to severe injuries or permanent deformities, despite all proper care given by the doctor during treatment. This is known as a medical maloccurrence. If the doctor can prove this before the court, it will be an absolute defence against malpractice.

Scenario 2:

Under IPC 92, the doctor can perform life-saving procedures on a patient with life-threatening injuries without obtaining consent. The guiding principle is whether the delay in treatment in order to obtain consent would result in harm to the patient. This is the doctrine of emergency. Under some circumstances like emergencies, informed consent may be neither possible nor necessary.

Scenario 3: 

If full disclosure is disadvantageous to the patient (e.g. in patients with anxiety), then the doctor can withhold certain information from the patient. However, he should disclose the full information to a competent relative of the patient. This is called therapeutic privilege.

Scenario 4:
Res Ipsa Loquitor means the thing or fact speaks for itself. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed. For example, swabs left in the abdominal cavity post laparotomy. The negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence. 

This doctrine applies to both civil and criminal negligence. All of the following conditions should be fulfilled for this doctrine:

  • In the absence of negligence, there would not have been any injury usually
  • The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.
  • The patient was not a part of contributory negligence.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who came for trekking in the Himalayas was brought to you by his friends. He had consumed some herb that looked like horse-radish (mooli ) that was offered by a local quack. The patient is staggering as he tries to walk and feels numbness in the skin. Eye findings reveal alternate miosis and mydriasis. Prompt primary treatment is administered but the patient succumbs a few hours later. Which of the following poisons is implicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of aconite poisoning.

Aconite grows in the Himalayas and is a potent poison causing numbness followed by tingling, hippus (alternate miosis-mydriasis), and death due to cardiovascular or respiratory collapse. Its root resembles a horse-radish and tastes sweet, hence, there is a risk of accidental poisoning. The active principle is an alkaloid called aconitine.

Other options:

  • Nerium odorum, commonly called kaner may also cause accidental poisoning. It causes muscle twitching and spasm rather than paralysis. It causes pupil dilation rather than a hippus. 
  • Croton tigillum, commonly known as Jamal Gota, causes severe gastrointestinal irritation and purging with vomiting. It may also cause abortion.
  • Strychnus curare is a spinal poison causing paralysis when introduced into the bloodstream. It causes nothing if ingested.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. Punishable as per Section 290 IPC
  2. Punishable as per Section 376 IPC
  3. Punishable as per Section 297 IPC
  1. In an empty factory, a man has forceful penetrative intercourse with a woman he kidnapped
  2. In a crowded railway station, an individual obtains sexual gratification when he rubs his private parts against a woman's back
  3. In a lonely graveyard, a person is caught performing a sexual act with a corpse
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-B, 2-A, 3-C

  • Case A is an example of rape, which is punishable under section 376 of the IPC. The definition of rape is under section 375 of the IPC and is as follows- A man is said to commit rape if he has sexual intercourse with a woman under circumstances falling under any of the six following descriptions:
    • First– Against her will.
    • Second – Without her consent.
    • Third – With her consent, when her consent has been obtained by putting her or any person in whom she is interested in fear of death or of hurt.
    • Fourth – With her consent, when the man knows that he is not her husband and that her consent is given because she believes that he is another man to whom she is or believes herself to be lawfully married.
    • Fifth – With her consent, when, at the time of giving such consent, by reason of unsoundness of mind or intoxication or the administration by him personally or through another of any stupefying or unwholesome substance, she is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which she gives consent.
    • Sixth – With or without her consent, when she is under eighteen years of age.
  • Case B is an example of Frotteurism. It refers to the act of obtaining sexual gratification by contact with another person (rubbing his private parts against female buttocks, breasts, thighs, etc. in crowds, etc). It is punishable under Sections 290 and 291 of the IPC, with a fine of up to Rs 200.
  • Case C is an example of Necrophilia. It refers to the desire for sexual intercourse with dead bodies. It is said to have a sadomasochistic foundation and that decomposition, foul smell, and coldness act as stimulants. Necrophagia is the extreme degree of sadism in which the person after mutilating the body, sucks or licks the wounds, bites the skin, drinks the blood, and eats the flesh of his victim to derive sexual pleasure. They are both punishable under section 297 of IPC, with a fine, up to 1-year imprisonment, or both.

questions.text: A patient with a condition related to high environmental temperature was brought to the hospital. Sweating is present in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Sweating is present in all of the given conditions except classic heatstroke.

Heat stroke/thermic fever/heat hyperpyrexia is characterized by a raised rectal temperature of more than 41°C. 

There is a loss of thermoregulatory function and failure of cutaneous circulation and sweating. The predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, old age, lack of acclimatization, and alcoholism.

Heatstroke can be of two types:

  • Classic heatstroke (CHS)is seen in those with chronic diseases that predispose them to heat-related illnesses. 
  • Exertional heat stroke(EHS) is seen in young, previously healthy people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures. T

Patients usually present with a sudden collapse. The skin is dry, flushed, and hot. Sweating is absent in CHS but present in about 50% of cases of EHS. Dry skin in the presence of hyperpyrexia is virtually pathognomonic. Tachypnea (rapid Kussmaul type of breathing), tachycardia, hypotension, and widened pulse pressure are other findings.

CNS dysfunction signs include delirium, coma, and convulsions. Thermal cardiomyopathy and heat-related reversible increase in cardiac biomarker levels are also seen. The ECG may display tachyarrhythmias, nonspecific ST-T wave changes, and heat-related ischemia or infarction. 

Other complications include rhabdomyolysis, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and multiorgan failure.

  • Continuous monitoring with a rectal thermistor (flexible thermometer)
  • Fluid resuscitation, as determined by the patient's volume status, urine output, and cardiopulmonary function
  • Correction of electrolyte and metabolic abnormalities (hyponatremia and hypoglycemia)
There is no role of antipyretics in the control of environmentally induced hyperthermia. They also exacerbate the complications (acute kidney injury, hepatic failure, DIC).

Hyperthermic anhydrosis / Desert syndrome - The symptoms are similar to those of heat exhaustion. After many days of intense generalised sweating, all areas of the body below the neck abruptly stop sweating, but the face and neck continue to perspire. This is due to the hyperkeratotic plugging of sweat glands causing the functional failure of the sweat gland below the neck.

questions.text: A farmer was rushed to the emergency after sustaining a sting on his right calf. The patient is conscious and oriented with stable vitals. On local examination of the wound, there is a hole in the center of a reddened area along with edema, pain, and reddening of the limb. There is no history of nausea, vomiting, or seizures. The agent responsible for the sting is shown below. Which of the following snakebites is similar to this organism's sting?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem with the image showing a scorpion points to a scorpion sting. The clinical findings of edema and pain of the limb with no neurological symptoms are consistent with hemolytic venom which is similar to that of Russel's viper.

Scorpions are eight-legged arthropods that have a hollow sting in the last joint of their tail, which secretes poison on stinging. The venom is a clear, colorless toxalbumen and is generally classified as either hemolytic or neurotoxic. 

The venom causes autonomic stimulation resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals. It also has a direct effect on the myocardium.

It can present as neurotoxicity with nausea, vomiting, extreme restlessness, fever, various types of paralysis, cardiac arrhythmias, convulsions, coma and cyanosis, respiratory depression, and death that occurs as a result of pulmonary edema or cardiac failure. This is similar to that of a cobra bite.

If the scorpion has hemolytic venom it mimics a viper bite where the reaction is mainly local, with edema, pain, and reddening. This usually lasts for one to two hours. 

Diagnosis is confirmed with ELISA.

Treatment:

  • The limb involved is immobilized and a tourniquet is secured above the level of sting. 
  • The sting is packed in ice and the wound is washed with a weak solution of ammonia, borax, or potassium permanganate after incision and suction
  • Local anesthetics may be used for pain relief
  • Specific antivenin is administered if species are identified.
  • Local swelling is controlled with the use of calcium gluconate
  • Restlessness and seizures are controlled with the use of barbiturates. The use of morphine is contraindicated.
  • Atropine is used for the prevention of pulmonary edema.
  • Prazosin can counteract the alpha-adrenergic effects of autonomic stimulation, such as hypertension

Other options :

Options A and D - The king cobra and the common krait have a venom that is neurotoxic. They present with nausea, vomiting, restlessness, fever, arrhythmias, and seizures.

Option B - Sea snake which is myotoxic. The main presentation is generalized rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: On noticing taurodontism in the postmortem reports of a body, you would suspect that the individual belongs to which of the following races?
questions.solution:
Taurodontism or bull tooth is most commonly associated with Mongoloid race. It is characterized by a wide and deep pulp cavity in molar teeth and fused and bent roots. 

Other common associations in Mongoloid teeth include enamel pearls, which are small nodules appearing on the tooth surface. This race is also frequently associated with shovel-shaped upper central incisors and a congenital absence of the third upper molar. 

Other options:

Negroid races are found to have large teeth, multiple cusps (up to 8) on their molars, and 2 lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars.

Caucasians have smaller lateral incisors than central incisors (seen especially in females), and long pointed canine roots. They also have small nodules on the lingual surface of their maxillary molars known as 'Carabelli's cusp', which are most commonly associated with Caucasian races.

questions.text: An investigating officer collects a bullet from the crime scene and compares it with a bullet from the firearm suspected to be used. Which of the following characteristic features will determine the specific firearm that was used?

choices.text: Make and model of the gun
Direction of twist of the rifling

questions.solution:
The secondary markings will determine the specific firearm that was used.

These markings, also known as individual or accidental characteristics, refer to the irregularities on the inner surface of the barrel itself, which are specific for that particular firearm. These markings are caused by the sticking of the particles of the bullet to the bore when shots are fired and are known as "metallic fouling." 

Secondary markings are used to identify a specific gun to the exclusion of all others by the process called bullet fingerprinting.

The class characteristics or the primary markings in a fired bullet are useful in identifying the make and model of the gun involved and are determined before the manufacture of the gun. These markings result from manufacturing specifications, design, and dimensions. They are formed when a bullet passes through a barrel and the sides are marked by the rifling of the barrel. 

Primary markings are based on the following factors:

(1) Caliber

(2) Number of lands and grooves

(3) Direction of twist of the rifling 

(4) Rate of the twist of the rifling

(5) Width of the lands and grooves 

The bullet found at the crime scene is known as a crime bullet or exhibit bullet. It is compared with a bullet fired from the suspected weapon, known as a test bullet. The suspected weapon is fired using the same brand and type of ammunition, into a box filled with cotton waste (bullet traps), a bag of rags, a sandbag, oiled saw-dust, blocks of ice, water tanks (bullet recovery tank), or against white blotting paper. Cleanly shaven fresh pork skins are used for comparison with patterns on human skin.

From the fired cartridge case, the caliber and type of cartridge can be determined. From the shape and size of the case and the stampings on the case head, its manufacturer can be determined. The marks left on the fired cartridges by the weapon can also help in the identification.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of ingestion of one uncrushed seed similar to that shown in the image below. He is asymptomatic at presentation. Which of the following can be anticipated in this case?
questions.solution:
The image shows seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica. No poisonous action is anticipated.

If swallowed uncrushed, the seeds of nux vomica have no poisonous action, as they are not dissolved in the gastrointestinal tract and are passed entirely in the feces.

Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postganglionic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. 

The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed. When crushed seeds are ingested, the symptoms are delayed for an hour or more.

Convulsions are produced as the reflex centers of the spinal cord are directly affected. The convulsions are first clonic but eventually become tonic.  Risus sardonicus results from the contraction of the jaws and facial muscles in which the corners of the mouth are drawn back. The convulsions are most marked in anti-gravity muscles so that the body typically arches in hyperextension, the posture known as opisthotonos. If the spasm involves the abdominal muscles, the body bends forward (emprosthotonos), or to the side (pleurosthotonos). If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature known as postmortem caloricity.

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

  • Convulsions - clonic-tonic type
  • Reflex increased
  • Awful taste
  • Mind is conscious
  • Pupils dilated
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

questions.text: The crown heel length of a 6-month-old fetus would likely be:
questions.solution:
According to Haase's modification of Morisson's law, the Age of the fetus during the last 5 months of pregnancy = Crown heel length(in cm)/5. So, crown heel length = age in months × 5 i.e. 6 × 5 = 30cm. Therefore, the crown heel length of a 6-month-old fetus is 30cm.

Rule of Haase: A rough method of calculating the age of the fetus. The length of the fetus is measured from the crown to the hell in centimeters. During the first five months of pregnancy, the square root of the length gives the approximate age of the fetus in months. E.g., a fetus of 16cm is four months old.

questions.text: Which of the following postmortem changes is not a feature of normal decomposition?
questions.solution:
Saponification or adipocere is a postmortem change which is not a feature of normal decomposition.

It is characterized by the formation of a waxy, greasy, and whitish substance with a sweet, rancid odor. it resembles the consistency of soap. The pattern of distribution includes areas of fatty tissues in the dead body. 

Adipocere consists primarily of fatty acids that are produced due to postmortem hydrolysis and the hydrogenation of body fats. It is a water-dependent process that involves the conversion of unsaturated liquid fats to saturated solid fats. 

Medicolegal importance is as follows:

  • It is the surest sign of death
  • It gives a rough estimate of the time since death and
  • The cause of death can be identified. In the face, the features are well preserved and therefore used in identification. 

Other options:

Option A: Right iliac fossa discoloration is the first external sign of decomposition, and is due to the action of C.welchii in the ileocecal portion of the gastrointestinal tract. Bacterially produced hydrogen sulfide combines with hemoglobin to give rise to sulphmethemoglobin which causes discoloration.

Option B: Subsequently, bacterial dissemination takes place through the blood vessels causing similar discoloration of the superficial blood vessels. A linear branching pattern is formed known as marbling.

Option C: The process of decomposition destroys the anatomic integrity of skin which leads to localized peeling known as skin slippage and loosening of skin of hands and feet known as degloving.

Abrasions are superficial wounds produced due to the destruction of the epidermis. Though exact age cannot be determined, based on healing and appearance of the wound, an estimated time can be given.

    • known as brush burns; are the most common type of abrasions

  • Imprint abrasions (patterned abrasions): caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin without any movement
    • Ex: fingernail, tire, grills, bicycle chain, bite marks
  • Friction abrasions (pressure abrasion): are caused by crushing of the superficial layers of the epidermis.
    • Ex: ligature marks around the neck in hanging,

questions.text: A forensic expert was asked to conduct an autopsy of an HIV-positive deceased man with a suspected homicidal death. He decides to do an in-situ in-part dissection followed by en block removal of the organs. Which of the following autopsy techniques is he following?
questions.solution:
The autopsy technique the forensic expert is following is the Rokitansky technique. 

In the Rokitansky technique, a local dissection (in-situ) is started from the neck and is trailed down followed by removing the organs as a block (en bloc). It is preferred in patients with highly transmissible diseases such as HIV or hepatitis B. 

A medicolegal autopsy is a postmortem examination of a body to ascertain evidence contributory to the cause of death. It is important to complete the autopsy in each and every case. This is done by examining all the organs and opening all the body cavities. 

Universal work precautions taken during the autopsy of an HIV-positive deceased are - 

  • All infected bodies should be wrapped and tied in double-layer plastic bags and tagged as biologically hazardous.
  • Workers having external injury or dermatitis should not handle the body.
  • Personal protective equipment should be worn.
  • Avoid accidental pricks and cuts from needles. 
  • Specimen should be properly labelled, filled with 10% formalin solution and handled with gloved hands.
  • Gauze and cotton should be collected in double plastic bags for incineration.
  • Instruments used for an autopsy should be dipped in 20% glutaraldehyde for 1/2 an hour, washed with soap or detergent and water dried and then rinsed with methylated spirit.
  • Freshly prepared sodium hypochlorite / 1:10 dilution bleach is used for disinfecting the autopsy room.
  • Electrical oscillating saw is used to open the cranial cavity to minimise aerosol splatter.
  • After the autopsy, all body orifices should be packed and body is wrapped in double plastic bags.
  • Body should be incinerated or burnt.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: An intern commits a negligent act in the hospital. You as his senior doctor will be held responsible for the negligent act as the intern is working under you. This is explained by _____.
questions.solution:
The senior doctor is responsible for the negligent act of a junior doctor, resident, intern, or assistant working under him by vicarious liability.

Vicarious liability is by which the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope. It is by the principle of 'respondeat superior' (let the superior answer).

When two doctors practice as partners, they are both responsible for each other's negligent acts. When 2 or more doctors independently attend a patient, each may be held liable for the negligence of others that he observes or in the ordinary course should have observed and allows it to continue without objection.

When an employee is being borrowed, the lending employer temporarily loses his control over this worker and the borrowing employer temporarily assumes control. This is known as borrowed servant doctrine.

Contributory negligence is any unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care from the patient's part or from the attendant. This act, along with the negligent act of the doctor has contributed to the injury. If there was no contributory negligence, the injury would not have occurred. The doctor's negligence is not the direct cause of the injury. Eg. refusal to take required treatment, getting discharged against the doctor's advice, etc.

Res ipsa loquitur in Latin means "the thing speaks for itself". If an untoward result happened that is thought to be due to deviation from the normal standards of care, or negligence, then the doctor should admit the problem. The doctor should take the responsibility to explain the issue to the patient and their family, and solve the problem by either initiating treatment or transferring care. There should be no charge for additional care or for further procedures.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of increased lacrimation, salivation, sweating, and urinary incontinence. Which of the following is likely to be responsible for the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the patient presents with increased lacrimation, salivation, sweating, and urinary incontinence which are muscarinic symptoms, likely due to pesticide(organophosphorus compounds) poisoning. 

Organophosphorus compounds are constituents of pesticides. They block the acetylcholinesterase thereby causing persistent parasympathetic muscarinic and nicotinic receptors activation resulting in the symptoms. They can be absorbed through the skin, mucosa, or gastrointestinal tract.

Four clinical syndromes are identified with respect to organophosphate exposure. They include: 

  • Acute poisoning - This results in CNS, muscarinic, nicotinic, and somatic motor manifestations.
  • Intermediate syndrome -  Usually observed 1-5 days after organophosphate exposure. It is characterized by paralysis of neck flexors, muscles innervated by cranial nerves, proximal limb muscles, and respiratory muscles.
  • Chronic toxicity - It is seen primarily in agricultural workers with daily exposure. It manifests as symmetrical sensorimotor axonopathy.
  • Organophosphate-induced delayed neuropathy - Characterized by cognitive dysfunction, extrapyramidal symptoms, and peripheral neuropathy. It can lead to flaccid paralysis and muscle wasting

A diagnosis can be made by measuring the pseudocholinesterase levels in RBC, which if less than 50%, confirms the diagnosis. Treatment involves the administration of atropine.  

Postmortem appearances - Congestion and frothy hemorrhagic exudate is seen in respiratory passages. Stomach contents smell of kerosene.

Other options: 

Option A: Arsenic clinical features can be divided into fulminant type, gastrointestinal type, or narcotic form. The fulminant type is characterized by death due to shock and peripheral vascular failure. The gastrointestinal type is a common form and is similar to food poisoning, akin to cholera. The narcotic form is characterized by giddiness, muscle tenderness, coma, and death.

Option B: Strychnine(spinal poison) consumption is responsible for opisthotonus, emprosthotonus, and pleurosthotonus. These symptoms occur due to convulsions and muscle rigidity caused by action on the spinal reflex centres. Risus sardonicus, where the jaws and facial muscles are contracted and drawn back, may also occur. 

Option D: Aconite(cardiac poison), if swallowed, causes tingling and numbness of the mouth, tongue, and pharynx. Salivation, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea then follow, and subsequently, the patient would develop dry mouth, thirst, and dysphagia. Paresthesia, ataxia, slurred speech, and muscle twitching. Hypotension and cardiac arrhythmia with AV block occur.

questions.text: According to the POCSO act, sexual harassment includes:

choices.text: Making a child to exhibit his/her body
Act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration
Sexual assault by a police officer

questions.solution:
According to POCSO act sexual harassment includes making a child exhibit his/her body.

The POCSO Act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines various forms of sexual offences which include:

  • Sexual harassment: A person is said to commit sexual harassment upon a child when such person with sexual intent,
    • Carries out any act with sexual connotations
    • Makes a child exhibit his/her body
    • Shows any object to a child in any form/media for pornographic purposes.
    • Repeatedly or constantly watches or contacts a child through any media.
    • Threatens to use in any form of media, a real or fabricated depiction through any mode, of any part of the body of a child. 
  • Sexual assault
    • Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration.
  • Aggravated sexual assault
    • Similar to sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated.
  • Penetrative sexual assault
    • An act with sexual intent that involves physical penetration.
  • Aggravated penetrative sexual assault
    • Similar to penetrative sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated.
  • Pornography - Using a child in any form of media for purposes of sexual gratification. 

The term aggravated is used for those assaults done: 

  • By a person in a position of trust or authority such as a police officer, security force, relative, or hospital staff.
  • In the course of communal violence.
  • On mentally & physically disabled.
  • Gang sexual assault.
  • Using deadly weapons.
  • Causing grievous hurt
  • On child < 12 years.

Other options - 

Option B - Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration is a sexual assault according to POCSO.

Option D - Sexual assault done by a police officer is an aggravated sexual assault according to POCSO. 

Option C - Gang penetrative sexual assault is defined as aggravated penetrative assault according to POCSO.

The International Day of Innocent Children Victims of Aggression is a United Nations observance each 4th June. This day affirms the UN's commitment to protect the rights of children.

questions.text: A primigravida comes with complaints of absent fetal movements. On ultrasound, there is no cardiac activity in the fetus and a gas shadow is seen in the aorta of the fetus. According to the findings, a minimum of how many hours have passed after the death of the fetus.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a primigravida with a history of absent fetal movements and USG showing absent cardiac activity and gas shadow in the aorta of the fetus indicate 12 hours have passed after intrauterine fetal death.

Robert's sign is a gas shadow in the great vessels like the aorta, seen in fetal demise in utero. The gas shadow in the chambers of the heart and great vessels may appear as early as 12 hours but it is difficult to interpret.

A process of aseptic autolysis that occurs after the intrauterine death of the fetus is known as maceration. This process occurs when the dead fetus remains in utero for 3-4 days and is surrounded by the liquor amnii. There is a risk of putrefaction occurring when air is allowed to enter the liquor amnii after the death of the fetus.

Signs of maceration - 

  • Earliest sign - reddening of the skin with peeling in 12 hours
  • Robert's sign - radiographic finding showing gas in the great vessels like the aorta in 12 hours
  • Large blebs containing a red serous or serosanguineous fluid appear at around 24 hours 
  • Serous cavities may contain a turbid reddish fluid after 48 hours
  • Spalding's sign -  due to shrinkage of the brain after death there is loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of the cranial vault. 
  • A sweetish and disagreeable odour
  • Distended abdomen and abnormally mobile or flexible joints
  • The body is soft and pliable and flattens out when placed on an even surface

Other signs of intrauterine death - 

  • Rigor mortis at delivery
  • Mummification - when intrauterine death occurs due to deficient blood supply. Scanty liquor amnii and the absence of air in the uterus favours mummification.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text: Fracture through the line shown in the image is called as?
questions.solution:
The line shown in the given image corresponds closely to the location of a hinge fracture of the base of the skull, also called a motorcyclist's fracture.

It is a basal linear fracture that passes across the floor of the middle cranial fossa, often following the petrous temporal or greater wing of the sphenoid bone into the pituitary fossa. This frequently continues symmetrically across the other middle fossa separating the base of the skull into two halves, usually being caused by a heavy blow on the side of the head and is associated with injuries to the brainstem (pontomedullary tears).

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: Which of the following post-mortem changes is a result of hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather?
questions.solution:
Hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather would result in adipocere formation, which is seen in image 4. 

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

  • Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):
    1. Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    2. Cessation of respiration
    3. Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death. It is seen in cellular death:
    1. Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    2. Eye changes
    3. Primary flaccidity of muscles
    4. Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling
    5. Postmortem lividity/Suggillation
    6. Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    1. Putrefaction
    2. Adipocere
    3. Mummification

Adipocere formation (Image 4) is a late sign of death. The transformation is brought about by the gradual hydrolysis and hydrogenation of pre-existing fats, including olein, into higher fatty acids. These higher fatty acids then join with calcium and ammonium ions to produce insoluble soaps, which since they are acidic, prevent putrefactive bacteria. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months. Still, in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 4 to 5 days after death. 

Image 1. Marbling: It is seen when blood in the vessels is hemolyzed to sulfate-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent  36–48 hours after death. It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Image 2. Cadaveric lividity: Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in most superficial layers of the dermis in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6 – 12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in.

Image 3. Mummification: It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air. It is a process of dehydration or drying and shriveling of the cadaver that occurs from the evaporation of water. The natural appearances of the body and general facial features are preserved.

questions.text: Which of the following options does not describe the following postmortem changes?
questions.solution:
Tattooing is not related to the above postmortem changes. The image shows suggillation.

 

Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discolouration of the superficial layers of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries. 

It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to engorged vessels showing through the skin seen on the dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity. 

This staining starts as mottled patches 1-3 hours following death and develops to a uniform area of staining in 3-6 hours. Full development and fixation of hypostasis occur within 6-12 hours. This finding usually develops within 4 hours and persists until putrefaction. Fixation of hypostasis occurs earlier in summer. It is delayed in asphyxial deaths and intracranial lesions.  

Any pressure prevents the capillaries from filling, such as the collar band, wrist band, belts, wrinkles in the clothes, etc. and such areas remain free from colour and are seen as strips or bands called vibices.

questions.solution:
In cases of freshwater drowning, hyperkalemia is seen due to hemolysis of swollen RBCs and not hypokalemia.

Freshwater is hypotonic to plasma and is rapidly absorbed from the alveoli and into the RBCs. The RBCs finally swell up and lyse resulting in the release of intracellular potassium causing hyperkalemia. Increased intravascular blood volume combined with hyperkalemia causes arrhythmia. 

Seawater is hypertonic to plasma and causing a shift of fluid from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary edema. There is a net decrease in blood volume causing a fall in blood pressure.

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with a history of acute onset of anxiety and hyperactivity. His friend gives a history of substance abuse. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, high blood pressure and dilated pupils were noted. The toxicity of which of the following drugs can be suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario patient presenting with anxiety, hyperactivity, tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis with a history of substance abuse points towards a diagnosis of cocaine toxicity leading to sympathetic toxidrome.

Cocaine is a CNS stimulant obtained from coca plants belonging to the family Erythroxylaceae. It is also known as Coke, snow and white lady. The route of intake is by snorting, IV route and smoking. Tattoos may be made to cover the injection marks.

It inhibits the uptake of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin.

At lower doses, it leads to alertness but at higher doses, it produces stereotyped behavior, involuntary actions, and paranoia. There is a transient euphoria. Tactile hallucinations (Magnan's symptom or cocaine bugs) are characteristic. 

There is a dose-dependent increase in heart rate and blood pressure. It causes dilation of pupils and is associated with chills and perspiration. In severe cases, intracranial bleeding due to increased blood pressure, and myocardial infarction due to coronary vasospasm can occur. Ultimately, the patient goes into a stage of depression with loss of reflexes, paralysis of muscles, cardiorespiratory failure, and coma.  

Management -  Administration of activated charcoal and gastric lavage with warm water and potassium permanganate in case of ingestion. Benzodiazepines to control heart rate/seizures. Amyl nitrite is the antidote given via inhalation. Thiamine 100 mg IV and Naloxone 2 mg IV can also be given.

Other options:

Option A - Benzodiazepines is a CNS depressant. They would present with dizziness, diplopia, dysarthria, ataxia and drowsiness. In overdose, respiratory depression and hypotension may occur, unlike the CNS stimulant effects of cocaine.

Option B - Cannabis acts on THC (tetrahydrocannabinol) receptors. It causes euphoria followed by narcosis. There is inattention, motor incoordination, ataxia, tremors, conjunctival suffusion, and somnolence, unlike cocaine which causes hyperactivity.

Option C - Heroin (opium) presents with an initial excitement followed by giddiness and headache. There is a fall in BP, heart rate, respiratory rate in the later stages and pupils are constricted.

questions.text: Which of the following anthropophagy artifacts is incorrectly paired with the typical causative agents?

choices.text: Ant bites - Irregular wound edges with long grooves

questions.solution:
Artefacts due to animal and insect bites are referred to as anthropophagy artefacts and those produced by extensive ant bites resemble that of abrasion.

Marks produced by insects such as ants and cockroaches are dry, and brown with irregular margins. They are usually seen in moist parts of the body like ears, armpits, groin, scrotum, anus, etc. Often they appear like antemortem abrasions(Option D). As they become dry, they resemble brush burns and do not show vital reactions. Extensive linear ant bites around the neck resemble ligature abrasion.

Irregular wound edges with long grooves are findings that are typically seen in rodent bites. Dog bites are associated with deep impressions of teeth in a small area. The resulting individual puncture wounds may resemble stab wounds (Option C). Cat bites appear similar to knife wounds, especially in bones(Option B)

Artefact is any change or feature introduced in a body after death, which leads to misinterpretation of medicolegally significant antemortem findings.

Other important types of artefacts: 

  • Agonal artefacts -  Autolytic rupture of the stomach, also known as gastromalacia, is characterized by the postmortem release of gastric contents into the peritoneal cavity. It may be accompanied by a diaphragmatic rupture with evidence of gastric contents in the chest cavity. 
  • Resuscitation artefacts - Intracardiac injections show contusion and blood in the pericardium. Superficial skin burns and ring-like contusions can be caused by defibrillators. Pneumothorax after placing a subclavian or internal jugular vein catheter.
  • Artefacts by handling of the body - Contusion of the occipital region. Undertaker's fracture is a subluxation of the lower cervical spine due to the tearing of the intervertebral disc at C6-C7. 
  • Artefacts introduced during autopsy -  Air in the blood vessels due to pulling of dura may mislead to a diagnosis of air embolism. Other artefacts include fracture of the hyoid bone, injury to blood vessels, and visceral damage due to rough handling of the tissues during autopsy.

questions.text: A police officer while investigating a case of infantile homicide asks a forensic expert to estimate the age of the dead infant. The forensic expert estimates the age as 3 months by counting the number of cross striations in the enamel of teeth. Which of the following methods has been used by the forensic expert for age estimation?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests that Boyde’s method is being used by the forensic expert for estimating the age of the dead infant.

Boyde’s method method is based on counting the number of cross striations in the enamel of teeth (incremental lines) from the neonatal line onwards. The neonatal line is formed soon after birth and can be seen in about 3 weeks or by electron microscopy 1–2 days after birth. This method is applicable mainly to estimate the age of dead infants.

Other options:

Option B- Stack’s method: Determination of age is done from the weight of the erupting teeth of the fetus/ infant. It can be used on both deciduous and permanent teeth in their erupting phase.

Option C- Miles' method: Age estimation is made on the basis of a comparison of the amount of wear on all three permanent molars with the baseline. It is used to determine the age beyond 25 years. 

Option D- Gustafson’s Method: It is based on physiological changes in teeth. It is used to determine the age between 25-60 years. Gustafson’s criteria include:

  • Attrition: Wear and tear changes of the occlusal surface.
  • Periodontosis: Regression of gums surrounding the tooth resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling.
  • Secondary dentin: Deposition of dentin in the pulp cavity.
  • Cementum apposition: Deposition of cementum in the root forming incremental lines.
  • Root resorption: Involves both cementum and dentin.
  • Transparency of the root: This is the most reliable criterion. Canals in dentin get filled with minerals and they become less transparent.

Note: Amino acid racemization is considered the most reliable destructive method of dental age estimation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old photographer presented with confusion, delirium, and corrosion near the mouth. He was found with an empty bottle containing hydrocyanic acid. He is tachycardic and hypotensive. Resuscitative measures are unsuccessful, and his body is sent for postmortem analysis. What would be the color of post-mortem hypostasis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of hydrocyanic acid (HCN) poisoning, and the colour of postmortem hypostasis in case of HCN poisoning is brick red. 

HCN is a toxic chemical acid found in bitter almonds, peaches, apples, cherries, etc. It has the smell of bitter almonds. It is usually present in its glycoside form, amygdalin, along with certain co-enzymes like emulsion complex, these co-enzymes hydrolyze amygdalin to release HCN. HCN is a common chemical used in leather tanning, electroplating, metal extractions, and photographic fixing. 

Mechanism of action: It is a protoplasmic poison releasing cyanide ions, which inhibit complex IV of cellular respiratory enzyme systems. It leads to histotoxic anoxia.

Postmortem findings: 

  • External: The smell of bitter almonds, brick red postmortem hypostasis. Rigor mortis appears early, and jaws are firmly closed.
  • Internal: In suspected cyanide poisoning cases, the cranial cavity should be opened first to perceive the bitter almond smell that is marked in brain tissue. Diffuse cerebral oedema such that white and gray matter cannot be differentiated, haemorrhages in the lungs.

Toxicological analysis: Preserve lungs to demonstrate the gas in a nylon bag. The spleen is the best specimen to demonstrate cyanide poisoning.

Laboratory diagnosis includes a classical triad of

  1. Narrow arterio-venous oxygen difference,
  2. Anion-gap metabolic acidosis, and
  3. Elevated lactate concentration.

HCN may be identified by gas chromatography or spectrophotometry.

Lee-Jones Test: This test indicates the presence of cyanide. The test can be positive for salicylates, too.

Treatment: Shift the patient to a room with fresh air and remove his clothes. Establish proper airway, breathing, and circulation. Inhalational amyl nitrate is administered, and 100% oxygen therapy is also given. Wash skin and eyes with large amounts of water to remove any contact poison, if any. A slow infusion of 3% sodium nitrate solution, followed by a slow infusion of 25% sodium thiosulfate solution, is given.

questions.text: A victim was recovered from the site of a terrorist attack. Which of the following conclusions can be made from the image shown below of the victim?

questions.solution:
From the image shown, it can be inferred that the victim has been hit by multiple shrapnel, possibly from an explosion. Shrapnel wounds are also called secondary blast injuries. 

Blast injury is a complex type of physical trauma, resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion that causes a sudden increase or decrease in atmospheric pressure.

TK Marshall (Marshall's triad) described the characteristic injuries associated with bomb explosions:

  • Abrasions
  • Bruises/contusions
  • Puncture lacerations
Blast injuries are classified as follows:
  • Primary injuries: These are caused by the effect of transmitted blast waves on gas-containing structures and are characterized by only internal injuries. 
  • Secondary injuries: These are injuries caused by shrapnel and other airborne debris propelled by the explosion. These injuries may affect any part of the body and sometimes result in penetrating trauma. Most casualties are caused by secondary injuries.
  • Tertiary injuries: These are caused by blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects.
  • Quaternary injuries: All other injuries caused by explosions that are not included in the above three categories, e.g. flash burns, crush injuries, respiratory effects due to toxic dust, and gas

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a wound with the linear splitting of the tissue, sharp margins, and crushed hair follicles, which is suggestive of an incised-looking lacerated wound. 

Incised-looking lacerated wounds are seen at sites where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue. A blunt force causes linear splitting of the tissue which results in the laceration resembling an incised wound. 

Common areas: Scalp, forehead, eyebrows, zygoma, lower jaw, perineum, shin, and iliac crest.

A laceration is a tear or a split in the skin, mucous membrane, muscle, or any internal organ produced by blunt force. The full thickness of the skin is penetrated.

Classification of a laceration:

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration) occurs when the skin is crushed between two hard objects
  • Stretch laceration occurs due to the over-stretching of the skin, beyond its elasticity.
  • Avulsion is a lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues. It may overhang the wound.
  • Tears occur due to tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue can occur from localized impact.
  • Cut lacerations occur due to an injury that leads to a deep and wide injury. 

Features of laceration:

  • Margins are irregular with pieces of tissue attached in between called tissue tags or bridges. Tears that are seen at the ends, diverging away from the main laceration are called swallow tails.
  • Bruising is seen around the margins.
  • Deeper tissues are unevenly divided with tissue tags.
  • Hair bulbs are crushed.
  • Depth of the wound contains abundant foreign material such as dust particles, paint material of the vehicle involved, etc
  • In skin lacerations, one of the margins overhangs the other helping in assessing the direction of the force.
  • A laceration, on healing, produces a permanent scar.

Other options -  

Option A:- Strech laceration - A flap of skin is peeled off from the underlying bone or deep fascia due to overstretching of the fixed skin, seen in running over by a motor vehicle. 

Option B:- Incised wound - produced by a sharp weapon. Wound margins are clear and regular with no tissue bridges, associated with profuse bleeding.

Option D:- Chop wound - produced by a heavy sharp weapon. A deep gaping wound with regular margins associated with bruising of the adjacent skin and crushing of the floor of the wound.

questions.text: The body of a woman found in a water body was brought for autopsy. There is frothing at the mouth, the hand is clenched with soil and weeds, and bloodstained froth is present in the lungs. The Gettler test reveals that the chloride content is 30 mg% lower on the left side of the heart compared to the right. With the above case scenario, which option best describes the drowning?
questions.solution:
The above case scenario shows the features of antemortem drowning in freshwater.

Frothing and cadaveric spasm are suggestive of antemortem drowning. The Gettler test findings are consistent with freshwater drowning.

Gettler test - Normally, the chloride content is 600 mg% on either side of the heart. A difference of more than 25 mg% between the right and the left sides is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.

Freshwater drowning - The chloride content is lower on the left side of the heart due to dilution by freshwater.

Saltwater drowning- The chloride content is higher on the left side of the heart due to the entry of saltwater and hemoconcentration.

Given below are the features of antemortem drowning.

  • Froth - The presence of copious amounts of fine, shaving-lather-like froth at the mouth and the nostrils is the most characteristic finding of antemortem drowning. It is caused by the vigorous agitation of the tracheal and bronchial mucous secretions, edema fluid, and alveolar surfactant during respiratory efforts. 
  • Cutis anserina - The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and grainy appearance of the skin. This resembles goose skin; hence, it is called cutis anserina.
  • Washerwoman’s hand - Maceration of the skin on the palms and soles gives a wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance due to submersion.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning. The material also indicates the place of submersion.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Face - It is bloated and discolored, with cyanosis.
  • Eyes - Conjunctiva are suffused and pupils dilated.
  • Tongue - It may be swollen and protruded.
  • Antemortem injuries - These may be sustained by striking objects, such as rocks, during the fall into the water body. Examination for such injuries must be performed only after the body is dry.

Internal findings:

  • Lungs - They appear voluminous and distended show ballooning. The cut section will exude copious amounts of frothy, bloodstained fluid.
  • Larynx, trachea, and bronchioles - The presence of sand, silt, and aquatic vegetation in the trachea and lower respiratory tract are characteristic findings of antemortem drowning.
  • Heart and blood vessels- Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. 
  • Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Stomach and small intestines- These organs may contain water in some cases. Water present in the small intestine is positive evidence of death by drowning.
  • Middle ear - The presence of water in the middle ear is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Brain - It is congested, and edematous, with loss of gray-white junction.


Options A, C, and D are not correct as the case does not show the findings of postmortem or saltwater drowning.

questions.text: A young girl was rushed to the emergency room in a delirious state. Her parents reported her to have consumed a wild fruit as shown below while on a camping trip. On examination, photophobia, staggering gait, flushing, and dry mucous membranes are noticed. The pupils are bilaterally dilated. Which of the following plant poisons she may have consumed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing cherry-like fruit is suggestive that the plant poison the patient may have consumed is Atropa belladonna. 

Atropa belladonna is a deliriant poison that acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine.

Clinical manifestations of Atropa belladonna poisoning include: 

  • Fever, flushing, rash
  • Neurological symptoms - delirium, slurred speech, headache, choreoathetosis, myoclonus, visual and auditory hallucinations, convulsions and coma
  • Eye symptoms - photophobia, blurred vision, dilated pupils poorly reactive to light
  • Cardiovascular symptoms - arrhythmia, tachycardia, hypertension
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms - severely dry mouth and throat, decreased bowel sounds, constipation, ileus
  • Renal symptoms - urinary retention

Anticholinergic symptoms include tachycardia, hypertension, flushing, dry mouth, mydriasis and urinary retention. 

Treatment - Conservative management with gastric lavage with activated charcoal. Benzodiazepines are used to control agitation and delirium. Physostigmine is a specific antidote, that should be given in cases of tachycardia, coma and respiratory arrest.

 

Other options - 

Option A - Datura poisoning also presents with similar symptoms, but the image given is not of datura stramonium.

Option B - Nicotiana tabacum is a cardiac poison, all parts of the plant are poisonous except the ripe seeds. Acute poisoning results in burning sensation, abdominal pain, hypersalivation, tachycardia, hypotension, and respiratory depression.

Option C - Ricinus poisoning leads to symptoms such as the burning of oral mucosa, salivation, nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhoea. It may also cause drowsiness, convulsions, delirium, and death. The entire plant is poisonous, but seeds are the most toxic and toxic principle is toxalbumin ricin which acts by blocking protein synthesis.

questions.text: Under McNaughten's rule, which of the following criteria is not valid to clear a mentally unsound person of all responsibility?

choices.text: Psychiatric illness while committing the crime
Inability to understand that the act is wrong

questions.solution:
The criterion of the presence of uncontrollable impulse is not included in McNaughten's rule. Therefore, it is not a valid criterion to clear a mentally unsound person of all criminal responsibility.

McNaughten's rule is followed by the British Courts of law to examine the liability of a mentally unsound person who has committed a crime. BNS 22 is the Indian adaptation of this rule. 

McNaughten's rule forms the basis of the legal test of insanity/the 'right or wrong' test. It states that a mentally unsound person is cleared of all criminal responsibility for the crime committed if the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of evidence of psychiatric illness.
  • Existence of psychiatric illness at the time of the commission of the crime.
  • Psychiatric illness is of such a degree that the person does not have the ability to understand the wrongness of the act, i.e., impaired intellectual ability. 

McNaughten's rule decide a person's soundness of mind based on the presence or absence of intellectual ability. However, it fails to consider any impairments in the person's emotional state or the presence of any uncontrollable/ irresistible impulses while committing the act.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman was found dead at a cafe around midnight. Her face was congested with marked petechiae and her tongue was protruded and swollen. On examination, signs of struggle and a pale transverse mark completely encircling her neck below the thyroid cartilage were noted. Which of the following is the likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and examination findings of a pale transverse mark completely encircling her neck below the thyroid cartilage with signs of struggle point toward a diagnosis of strangulation by ligature.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument.

When strangulation is done by using a ligature like a constricting band or rope, it is called ligature strangulation. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark which is transverse and completely encircling the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth.

Other options:

Option A: In a cafe coronary syndrome, the victim is usually healthy but grossly intoxicated and dies suddenly and unexpectedly during a meal with no signs of respiratory distress or of asphyxia. The autopsy reveals a bolus of food lodged in the pharynx or larynx. The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition.

Option B: Throttling or manual strangulation occurs due to compression of the neck by humans leading to asphyxia. Thumb impression and finger marks may be seen over the victim's neck. It is characterized by autopsy findings showing carotid intimal tear and muscle hematoma with nail marks on the neck and absence of ligature marks.

Option D: Mugging is a method of strangulation wherein the neck of the victim is caught in the bend of the assailant's elbow as shown below. Pressure is usually applied either in front of the larynx or at one or both sides of the neck.

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins. Although a detailed evaluation revealed the same gestational age, the father believed that the children did not belong to him and requested DNA testing. After testing, it was found that one child did not belong to him. What is this case best described as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario where twins have different fathers is suggestive of heteropaternal superfecundation.

Superfecundation is the fertilization of 2 different ova in the same menstrual cycle (as indicated by the same gestational age) by separate acts of coitus. It can also occur after artificial reproductive therapy. Hence, after embryo transfer, intercourse must be avoided. The term heteropaternal superfecundation refers to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins. This implies that the twins are half-siblings. Such cases may give rise to doubts about adultery and infidelity. 

Other options -

Option A: In a spurious pregnancy(pseudocyesis, phantom pregnancy), a woman believes she is pregnant despite there being no actual pregnancy. It is a psychological disorder observed in infertile women, who have an intense desire for a child. These patients present with all subjective symptoms of pregnancy associated with an increase in the size of the abdomen. Obstetric examination and USG or immunological tests do not show any signs of pregnancy.

Option C: In feigned pregnancy, a woman feigns pregnancy after the death of her husband and later produces a child to claim property and compensation. This child is known as a supposititious child. 

Option D: Superfetation is the fertilization of 2 different ova released in different menstrual cycles (i.e. ovulation and fertilization during pregnancy). This can occur within 12 weeks of pregnancy, after which the decidual space is obliterated; a detailed evaluation will reveal disparities in gestational ages varying from 1-3 weeks.

questions.text: All are features of cadaveric spasm except:

choices.text: It cannot be produced by any method after death.

questions.solution:
Cadaveric spasm doesn’t indicate time since death. It only indicates the manner of death. Rigor mortis indicates the time of death. 

Cadaveric spasm/ instantaneous rigor/ cataleptic rigidity/ death clutch is a phenomenon where a group of muscles in a state of contraction at the time of death remains contracted after death until molecular death occurs. It occurs immediately after death. There is no stage of primary relaxation. It cannot be produced by any method after death and it is not simulated by any other condition. It is an antemortem phenomenon. It is seen in cases of deaths coupled with emotional disturbances like:

  • In case of excitement, fear, severe pain
  • Exhaustion at the time of death
  • Cerebral hemorrhage
  • Injury to the nervous system
  • Drowning
  • Strychnine poisoning

Examples:

  • In case of drowning, weeds and grass caught in hand during struggle remain firmly grasped even after death. This indicates that the person was alive when entering the water
  • In case of suicides, weapons remain firmly grasped in the hand
